tasks.task: Participating in or observing mob grazing practices
subtasks: Understanding the concept of high stocking density (20,000 to 250,000 pounds of live weight per acre)
Adjusting grazing frequency to manage forage consumption and soil health (e.g., moving livestock once to several times a day)
Assessing forage consumption and trampling effects through physical sampling and analysis (e.g., clipping vegetation, tracking residual biomass)
Evaluating harvest efficiency (percentage of forage consumed or trampled) and comparing it to conventional grazing practices (e.g., "take half, leave half" rule)
Assessing the balance between soil health improvement (trampling, organic matter addition) and plant health sustainment
Calculating stocking rates and carrying capacities for intensive grazing systems (e.g., 50,000 to 200,000 pounds of live weight per acre)
Monitoring animal performance (e.g., body condition, compensatory gain) during short-intensity grazing periods
Adapting grazing management based on local rainfall and vegetation conditions (e.g., different stocking densities in eastern vs. western South Dakota)
Documenting and sharing experiences and practices through videos, reports, and network collaboration among producers
